DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: the operation.
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of guests hiding in the seaside luxury Marriott Hotel in Panama City cheered when a battalion of elite U.S. airborne troops shot their way through a neighborhood to reach the building late Wednesday night, ending a day of terror. Cheney said the Pentagon had received conflicting reports about American hostages. ``It's sort of a floating crap game,'' he said. ``There may well still be some Americans held, but at this point we haven't been able to confirm specific identities or specific numbers.'' Bush ``is pleased by the military precision and smoothness of the operation,'' said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He said Bush would take a planned vacation in Texas next week. Cheney gave this situation report today: ``The organized resistance by the Panamanian forces has virutally ended. What we still have, though, is a situation in which there are a fairly large number of so-called Dignity Battalion members that are loose in the streets, many of them armed. ``So it's still a somewhat chaotic situation. Our forces are still involved in some cases in firefights. And it's not complete yet, but we've made major progress.'' In his speech, Bush extended official diplomatic recognition to a new Panamanian government headed by Guillermo Endara, the opposition candidate in last May's elections voided by Noriega _ and moved swiftly to bolster him. Ambassador Arthur Davis returned to Panama for the first time since the elections. At a heavily guarded news conference on a military base attended only by a poo of Washington-based reporters, Davis said he was bringing an economic recovery plan for discussion with Panama's new leaders. He made no promise of U.S. aid except to point out that $700 million in assets would be returned as a result of Bush's decision to lift economic sanctions. Davis added that ``deep down'' he thought leaders of other regional countries would be happy to have Noriega gone, despite their stated opposition to U.S. military intervention. The United States defended its decision at the United Nations and at the Organization of American States meeting in Washington. Vice President Dan Quayle spoke by telephone with Endara's vice presidents, Billy Ford and Ricardo Arias Calderon, and administration officials also said privately he might visit Panama next month in a gesture that would dramatize administration support. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said the bounty on Noriega's head would come from an existing drug enforcement fund. The reward is coupled with an offer of $150 per weapon to Noriega loyalists who surrender their firearms. The assault was the first time U.S. military force had been used against a foreign government since the 1986 air raid on Libya and the first full-fledged assault since the invasion of Grenada in 1983. It came after American forces sat by, inactive, on Oct. 3 when dissident Panamanian officers attempted a coup and briefly held Noriega _ an incident that subjected Bush to congressional criticism for timidity and indecision.
